text.strong: ‌Who will complete this questionnaire?‌

label.text: Mother or other female guardian
Father or other male guardian
Other

text.em: ‌Please answer this question with reference to <the student who brought this questionnaire home>.‌

text.strong: ‌Thinking back to when your child was about 10 years old, how often would your child have done these things?‌

text.em: ‌(Please tick only one box in each row.)‌

label.text: Watched TV programmes about science
Read books on scientific discoveries
Watched, read or listened to science fiction
Visited web sites about science topics
Attended a science club
Construction play, e.g.<Lego bricks>
Took apart technical devices
Fixed broken objects or items, e.g. broken electronic toys
Experimented with a science kit, electronics kit, or chemistry set, used a microscope or telescope
Played computer games with a science content
Observed animal behaviour (e.g. bird watching)
Participated in gardening activities
Visited a science museum

text.strong: ‌In what language did most of the activities in the previous question take place?‌

label.text: <Test language>
<National addition 413>
<National addition 414>
<English>
<National addition 402>
<National addition 403>
Another language

text.strong: ‌How often do you or someone else in your home do the following things with your child?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Discuss how well my child is doing at school
Eat <the main meal> with my child around a table
Spend time just talking to my child
Discuss political or social issues with my child
Help my child with his/her science homework
Obtain science-related materials (e.g. applications, software, study guides etc.) for my child
Discuss with my child how science can be applied in everyday life
Talk to my child about the importance of <completing ISCED 3>
Talk to my child about any problems he/she may have at school
Ask my child about how he/she is getting along with other students at school
Encourage my child to get good <marks>
Take an interest in what my child is learning at school
Talk to my child about his/her future education
Ask my child what he/she did in school that day
Discuss <science related career> options with my child
We are interested in what you think about the need for scientific skills in the job market today.

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Employers generally appreciate strong scientific knowledge and skills among their employees.
It is an advantage in the job market to have good scientific knowledge and skills.
The following questions refer to <science-related careers>. A <science-related career> is one that requires studying a science course at a university level.
Examples of <science-related careers> include science teacher, engineer, weather forecaster, optician and medical doctor.

text.strong: ‌Please answer the questions below.‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Does anybody in your family (including you) work in a <science-related career>?
Does your child show an interest in working in a <science-related career>?
Do you expect your child will go into a <science-related career>?
Has your child shown interest in studying science after completing <secondary school>?
Do you expect your child will study science after completing <secondary school>?
Science is an important part of the PISA study. We are interested in parents’ opinions on science and on environmental issues.
The following question asks about your views towards science.

text.strong: ‌How much do you agree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please tick only one box in each row.)‌

label.text: Advances in <broad science> usually improve people’s living conditions.
<Broad science> is important to help us to understand the natural world.
Some concepts in <broad science> help me to see how I relate to other people.
Advances in <broad science> usually help to improve the economy.
There are many opportunities for me to use <broad science> in my everyday life.
<Broad science> is valuable to society.
<Broad science> is very relevant to me.
I find that <broad science> helps me to understand the things around me.
Advances in <broad science> usually bring social benefits.
<Broad science> can help solve global environmental crises.

text.strong: ‌Do you see the environmental issues below as a serious concern for yourself and/or others?‌

text.em: ‌(Please tick only one box in each row.)‌
‌This is a serious concern for me personally as well as others‌
‌This is a serious concern for other people in my country but not for me personally‌
‌This is a serious concern only for people in other countries‌
‌This is not a serious concern for anyone‌

label.text: Air pollution
Energy shortages
Extinction of plants and animals
Clearing of forests for other land use
Water shortages
Nuclear waste
Extreme weather conditions
Contact with diseases that can pass from other animals to humans
The causes of climate change
The effects of climate change
Water pollution

text.strong: ‌Do you think problems associated with the environmental aspects below will improve or get worse over the next 20 years?‌

text.em: ‌(Please tick only one box in each row.)‌

label.text: Air pollution
Energy shortages
Extinction of plants and animals
Clearing of forests for other land use
Water shortages
Nuclear waste
Extreme weather conditions
The causes of climate change
The effects of climate change
Water pollution

text.strong: ‌During <the last academic year>, have you participated in any of the following school-related activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Discussed my child’s behaviour with a teacher on my own initiative
Discussed my child’s behaviour on the initiative of one of his/her teachers
Discussed my child’s progress with a teacher on my own initiative
Discussed my child’s progress on the initiative of one of their teachers
Participated in local school government, e.g. parent council or school management committee
Volunteered in physical or extra-curricular activities (e.g. building maintenance, carpentry, gardening or yard work, school play, sports, field trip)
Volunteered to support school activities (volunteered in the school library, media centre, or canteen, assisted a teacher, appeared as a guest speaker)
Attended a scheduled meeting or conferences for parents
Talked about how to support learning at home and homework with my child’s teachers
Exchanged ideas on parenting, family support, or the child’s development with my child’s teachers
Shared my own knowledge with students and/or teachers
Exchanged information on how to use <digital resources> in school and at home with my child’s teachers

text.strong: ‌During <the last academic year>, has your participation in activities at your child’s school been hindered by any of the following issues?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: The meeting times were inconvenient.
I was not able to get off from work.
I had no one to take care of my child/ children.
The way to school is unsafe.
I had problems with transportation.
I felt unwelcome at my child’s school.
I feel generally awkward in a school.
My <language skills> were not sufficient.
I think participation is not relevant for my child’s development.
I do not know how I could participate in school activities.
My child does not want me to participate.
I believed the school was unsafe.
I could not go to the school because of the COVID-19 pandemic.
We are interested in what you think about your child’s school.

text.strong: ‌How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Most of my child’s school teachers seem competent and dedicated.
Standards of achievement are high in my child’s school.
I am happy with the content taught at my child’s school.
I am happy with the instructional methods used in my child’s school.
I am satisfied with the disciplinary atmosphere in my child’s school.
My child’s progress is carefully monitored by the school.
My child’s school provides regular and useful information on my child’s progress.
My child’s school does a good job in educating students.
My child’s school provides an inviting atmosphere for parents to get involved.
My child’s school provides effective communication between the school and families.
My child’s school involves parents in the school’s decision-making process.
My child’s school offers parent education (e.g. <courses on family literacy>) or family support programmes (e.g. <to assist with health, nutrition>).
My child’s school informs families about how to help students with homework and other school-related activities.
My child’s school cooperates with <community services> to strengthen school programmes and student development.
My child’s school provides <school science> achievement data directly to parents or guardians.
Results from <social and emotional skills> assessments are provided directly to parents or guardians.
My child’s school uses the results from <standardised tests> to inform parents or guardians about their child’s progress.
My child’s school uses the results from teacher-developed tests to inform parents or guardians about their child’s progress.
In my child’s school, <digital reources> are used well to support the students’ learning.
In my child’s school, <digital resources> are used well to communicate with parents or guardians.

text.em: ‌We are interested in the options you had as parents when choosing the school your child is currently attending.‌

text.strong: ‌Which of the following statements best describes the schooling available to students in your location?‌

label.text: There are two or more other schools in this area that compete with the school my child is currently attending.
There is one other school in this area that competes with the school my child is currently attending.
There are no other schools in this area that compete with the school my child is currently attending.

text.strong: ‌How important are the following reasons for choosing a school for your child?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: The school is at a short distance to home.
The school has a good reputation.
The school offers particular courses or school subjects.
The school adheres to a particular <religious philosophy>.
The school has a particular approach to <pedagogy/didactics, e.g. example>.
Other family members attended the school.
The children of friends or other people we trust attended the school.
Expenses are low (e.g. tuition, books, room and board).
The school has financial aid available, such as a school loan, scholarship, or grant.
The school has an active and pleasant school climate.
The academic achievements of students in the school are high.
There is a safe school environment.
The school has an international student body.
The school offers exchange programmes with schools in other countries.
The school has a focus on foreign language instruction.
The school has a focus on digital technologies.
The school has innovative practices using <digital resources>.

text.strong: ‌In what country were the following people in the child’s family born?‌

text.em: ‌(Please tick only one answer per column.)‌

label.text: <Country of test>

<Country L>

text.strong: ‌How many languages, including the language(s) you speak at home, do you speak well enough to converse with others?‌

label.text: One
Two
Three
Four or more

text.strong: ‌Which qualification do you expect your child to complete?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <ISCED level 2>
<National addition 415>
<National addition 416>
<ISCED level 3.3>
<National addition 421>
<ISCED level 3.4>
<ISCED level 4>
<National addition 417>
<National addition 418>
<National addition 419>
<ISCED level 5>
<ISCED level 6>
<National addition 420>
<ISCED level 7>
<ISCED level 8>

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: When my child does well I tell them they worked hard.
If my child does well, I tell them how smart they are.
Even if my child does poorly in a subject, I would still believe in and respect my child.
If my child did well, I would be proud of how hard they tried.
If my child did poorly, I would help them understand what they could do differently to succeed.
If my child does poorly, it means they didn’t try enough.

text.strong: ‌Did your child regularly attend an arrangement with one of the following main purposes prior to <grade 1 in ISCED 1>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Supervision and care (e.g. <national examples>)
Early childhood educational development (e.g. <national examples>)
Pre-primary education (e.g. <national examples>)

text.strong: ‌At what ages did your child attend an <early childhood education and care arrangement> prior to <grade 1 in ISCED 1>?‌

label.text: Up to age 1
Age 1
Age 2
Age 3
Age 4
Age 5
Age 6
Age 7

text.strong: ‌What was the most important reason why your child attended an <early childhood education and care arrangement>?‌

label.text: Attendance was mandatory.
We/I could not care for the child (e.g. work, illness).
We/I wanted additional learning stimulation for the child (e.g. social, academic).
Most other children attended an <early childhood education and care arrangement>.

text.strong: ‌How many hours per week did your child attend an <early childhood education and care arrangement> at the age of three years?‌

label.text: 0 hours per week
Up to 10 hours per week
11-20 hours per week
21-30 hours per week
31-40 hours per week
41-50 hours per week
51 hours per week or more

text.strong: ‌Did your child attend the following additional instructions during <ISCED 1>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <Enrichment lessons> in <test language>
<National addition 422>
<Remedial lessons> in <test language>
<National addition 423>
<Enrichment lessons> in mathematics
<Remedial lessons> in mathematics
<Enrichment lessons> in science
<Remedial lessons> in science

text.strong: ‌Including yourself, how many parents or guardians take care of your child and provide money or resources?‌

label.text: One
Two
Three or more

text.strong: ‌How many <digital devices> with screens are there in your home?‌

text.em: ‌(Count all the devices including televisions, computers, tablets, e-book readers, and smartphones.)‌

label.text: There are no <digital devices> with screens.
One
Two
Three
Four
Five
6 to 10
More than 10
Please answer the following question thinking just of expenses related to <the student who brought this questionnaire home>.

text.strong: ‌In the last twelve months, about how much have you paid to educational providers for services?‌

text.em: ‌In determining this, please include any tuition fees you pay to your child’s school, any other fees paid to individual teachers in the school or to other teachers for any tutoring your child receives, as well as any fees for cram school.‌
‌Do not include the costs of goods like sports equipment, school uniforms, computers or textbooks if they are not included in a general fee (that is, if you have to buy these things separately).‌

label.text: Nothing
<More than $0 but less than $W>
<$W or more but less than $X>
<$X or more but less than $Y>
<$Y or more but less than $Z>
<National addition 427>
<National addition 428>
<$Z> or more

text.strong: ‌What is your annual household income?‌

text.em: ‌Please add together the total income, before tax, from all members of your household.‌
‌Please remember we ask you to answer questions only if you feel comfortable doing so, and that all responses are kept strictly confidential.‌

label.text: Less than <$A>
<$A> or more but less than <$B>
<$B> or more but less than <$C>
<$C> or more but less than <$D>
<$D> or more but less than <$E>
<National addition 424>
<National addition 425>
<National addition 426>
<National addition 427>
<$E> or more

text.strong: ‌Think about how your child uses <digital resources> outside of school. How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements.‌

text.em: ‌<Digital resources> refer to digital devices or hardware (e.g. computers, tablets, smartphones, 3D printers), software (e.g. programs, apps, communications tools, educational learning tools), and online resources (e.g. web sites, web portals).‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: My child turns off notifications from social networks and apps on his/her <digital devices> when he/she goes to sleep.
My child feels nervous/anxious when he/she doesn’t have his/her <digital device> nearby.
My child uses <digital resources> for learning activities outside of school.
My child spends too much time playing videogames.
My child spends too much time on social media.

text.strong: ‌Do the following statements apply to you?‌

text.em: ‌<Digital resources> refer to digital devices or hardware (e.g. computers, tablets, smartphones, 3D printers), software (e.g. programs, apps, communications tools, educational learning tools), and online resources (e.g. web sites, web portals). ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I define rules about how long or when my child is allowed to use <digital resources>.
I monitor what my child does when using <digital resources>.
I set up filters to prevent my child from accessing inappropriate content online.
My child can use <digital resources> without any restriction.
I talk to my child about what he/she does on the internet.
I encourage my child to explore and learn things on the Internet.

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌<Digital resources> refer to digital devices or hardware (e.g. computers, tablets, smartphones, 3D printers), software (e.g. programs, apps, communications tools, educational learning tools), and online resources (e.g. web sites, web portals).‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Parents should use <digital resources> to communicate with their child’s teachers and school.
Schools should allow parents to track the progress of their children at school using <digital resources>.
Schools should put a strong focus on teaching programming and computer science.
Schools should put a strong focus on teaching students how to assess the quality of information online.
Schools should put a strong focus on teaching students how to use <digital resources> safely and ethically.

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your child?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: My child is curious to learn new things on his/her school subjects.
My child is good at learning new things on his/her own.
My child asks questions whenever he/she does not understand something.
My child is good at managing his/her emotions when learning (e.g., frustration, anxiety, boredom).
My child should improve his/her approach to learning.
My child should make more efforts to revise his/her work and check his/her understanding.
My child tries to find solutions to school assignments on his/her own before asking for help.
My child welcomes comments from me on his/her work.
My child is attentive to the feedback he/she receives from teachers.

text.strong: ‌To what extent are you able to do the following tasks using <digital resources>?‌

text.em: ‌<Digital resources> refer to digital devices or hardware (e.g. computers, tablets, smartphones, 3D printers), software (e.g. programs, apps, communications tools, educational learning tools), and online resources (e.g. web sites, web portals). ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌I struggle to do this on my own‌
‌I can do with a bit of effort‌

label.text: Search for and find relevant information online
Assess the quality of information you find online
Write or edit text for a formal document such as a CV (e.g. using <Google® Docs™>, <Microsoft® Word>)
Create a multi-media presentation (with sound, pictures, or video)
Create or edit videos (e.g. <iMovie, Final Cut Pro, InShot>)
Create or edit music (e.g. <Audacity, GarageBand>)
Create a computer program (e.g., in <Scratch>, <Python>, <Java>)
Collect and record data (e.g., using data loggers, <Microsoft® Access™>, <Google® Form>, <Excel>)
Build or edit a webpage (e.g. using <WordPress>)
Create shared documents for collaboration with others (e.g. using <Google® Docs™, Dropbox>)
Use drawing or graphic software and applications
Explain how my personal data are being collected and shared by any particular app or website
Assess the quality of information generated by Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.em: ‌The following two questions concern the mother’s job:‌

text.strong: ‌What is the mother’s main job? (e.g. school teacher, kitchen-hand, sales manager)‌
‌What does the mother do in her main job? (e.g. teaches high school students, helps the cook prepare meals in a restaurant, manages a sales team)‌

text.em: ‌The following two questions concern the father’s job:‌

text.strong: ‌What is the father’s main job? (e.g. school teacher, kitchen-hand, sales manager)‌
‌What does the father do in his main job? (e.g. teaches high school students, helps the cook prepare meals in a restaurant, manages a sales team)‌
‌Is the mother working as an employee or is she self-employed?‌

label.text: Employee (working for someone else)
Self-employed (has her own business, is her own boss)

text.strong: ‌At her job, does the mother have any formal responsibility for supervising the work of other employees?‌

label.text: 1-10 people
More than 10 people
No

text.strong: ‌Is the father working as an employee or is he self-employed?‌

label.text: Employee (working for someone else)
Self-employed (has his own business, is his own boss)

text.strong: ‌At his job, does the father have any formal responsibility for supervising the work of other employees?‌

label.text: 1-10 people
More than 10 people
No
